page.title: 01LITTONDALE, NORTH YORKSHIRE
page.content: Littondale is an offshoot of Wharfedale in the Yorkshire Dales National Park. It is a U-shaped valley, about eight miles long, down which the River Skirfare flows to join the Wharfe. The valley bottom is mainly meadow and pasture, which gives way to rough grazing. Above the grazing are escarpments, typical of limestone country. Beyond the escarpments are the moor tops, some of which are covered with heather. Sheltering in the valley bottom are five villages. Hawkswick is the first at the eastern end of the Dale, then Arncliffe some three and a half miles and Litton some five and a half miles up the Dale. At the top end of the Dale are the villages of Halton Gill and Foxup.
